notes_translated.fr:
Les Données nationales sur la couverture à large bande représentent l'information de couverture à travers le Canada des fournisseurs de services à large bande avec leur type de technologie associé. L’information de couverture est agrégée et déployée sur une grille d'hexagones, qui couvrent chacun des zones d’environ 25 km carrés. La disponibilité des services Internet à large bande est fournie selon des balises de vitesses de téléchargement/téléversement (5/1, 10/2, 25/5 et 50/10 Mb/s) où plus de 75% du total des logements à l'intérieur d'un hexagone ont accès à des services à large bande atteignant ces balises.

Afin d’augmenter le détail des données accessibles au public, ISDE et le CRTC fournissent des données colligées et anonymes sur les services de large bande d’après le modèle statistique des pseudo-logements. La disponibilité des services Internet de large bande est ainsi décrite à une plus petite échelle et avec plus de précision. Ces données sont disponibles ci-bas sous la ressource "Sous-ensemble DNLB PHH Vitesses". Pour plus d'information à propos du modèle statistique de pseudo-logement, référez-vous au jeu de données [Distribution démographique pseudo-logement](https://ouvert.canada.ca/data/fr/dataset/b3a1d603-19ca-466c-ae95-b5185e56addf "Distribution démographique pseudo-logement").

Une représentation des services à large par segments de routes individuels de 250 m peut maintenant être téléchargées sous la ressource "Routes DNLB". Cet ensemble de données fut généré en transposant l'information du Sous-ensemble DNLB PHH aux plus près des arcs de routes définis dans les Fichiers du réseau routier de Statistique Canada. Les routes identifiées furent divisées en segments d'approximativement 250 m.

**NOUVEAU:**
Des données ont été ajoutées afin d'inclure les nouvelles couches de présentation publiées sur la [Carte nationale des services Internet à large bande](https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/sitt/bbmap/hm.html?lang=fra "Carte nationale des services Internet à large bande").
notes_translated.en:
The National Broadband Data represents coverage information across Canada for existing broadband service providers with their associated technology types. The coverage information is aggregated and deployed over a grid of hexagons, which cover areas of roughly 25 square km each. Broadband Internet service availability is provided for download/upload speed markers (5/1, 10/2, 25/5 and 50/10 Mbps) where more than 75% of total dwellings covered within the hexagon have access to broadband service offerings meeting these markers.

In order to improve the granularity of the broadband data, ISED and the CRTC are providing aggregated and anonymous broadband services data based on the pseudo-household statistical model, hence achieving higher precision in depicting the broadband Internet 
 service availability. This information is available below under the "NBD PHH Speeds" resource. For more information on the pseudo-household statistical model, refer to the [Pseudo-Household Demographic Distribution](https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/b3a1d603-19ca-466c-ae95-b5185e56addf "Pseudo-Household Demographic Distribution") dataset.

A representation of broadband services per 250m road segments is now available for download under the “NBD Roads” resource. To generate this dataset, the NBD PHH Speeds information was projected over the nearest road arc from Statistics Canada’s Road Network File, and those roads were spliced in approximately 250m segments.

**NEW:**
The data has been augmented to include new presentation layers as published on the [National Broadband Map](https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/sitt/bbmap/hm.html?lang=eng "National Broadband Map").

The National Broadband Data represents coverage information across Canada for existing broadband service providers with their associated technology types. The coverage information is aggregated and deployed over a grid of hexagons, which cover areas of roughly 25 square km each. Broadband Internet service availability is provided for download/upload speed markers (5/1, 10/2, 25/5 and 50/10 Mbps) where more than 75% of total dwellings covered within the hexagon have access to broadband service offerings meeting these markers.

In order to improve the granularity of the broadband data, ISED and the CRTC are providing aggregated and anonymous broadband services data based on the pseudo-household statistical model, hence achieving higher precision in depicting the broadband Internet 
 service availability. This information is available below under the "NBD PHH Speeds" resource. For more information on the pseudo-household statistical model, refer to the [Pseudo-Household Demographic Distribution](https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/b3a1d603-19ca-466c-ae95-b5185e56addf "Pseudo-Household Demographic Distribution") dataset.

A representation of broadband services per 250m road segments is now available for download under the “NBD Roads” resource. To generate this dataset, the NBD PHH Speeds information was projected over the nearest road arc from Statistics Canada’s Road Network File, and those roads were spliced in approximately 250m segments.

The data has been augmented to include new presentation layers as published on the [National Broadband Map](https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/sitt/bbmap/hm.html?lang=eng "National Broadband Map").
